executive_summary: Over the past decade, camera stores have faced declining revenue amid the proliferation of smartphone ownership and strong price-based competition posed by large consumer electronic stores and e-commerce sites. These other retailers have been better able to capture what demand for cameras remains as smartphones continue to siphon away demand for digital cameras. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the industry's decline as foot traffic at bricks-and-mortar stores dropped off, and the revenue growth in 2021 brought by pent-up demand wasn't enough to offset previous losses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Camera Stores industry's revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 4.7% over the past five years – including an estimated 2.6% drop in the current year – and is expected to total $3.2 billion in 2023, with profit set to compress to 1.7%.

While consumers once would pick up a camera to take a family photo or pic from their vacation, the proliferation of smartphones has made standalone cameras unnecessary. Consumers prefer the convenience smartphones provide, as they can share images they take on social media in mere seconds.

Camera stores, as bricks-and-mortar retailers, rely on solid foot traffic to ensure sales, but the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic suspended in-person attendance at camera stores. Revenue plummeted in 2020 as consumer confidence and travel fell and cut demand for cameras, and what little demand was left was captured by online retailers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Struggling to compete with other retailers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Online retailers like Amazon are able to offer a wider range of camera products at lower price because of their lack of physical space limitations, while mass merchandisers are also able to leverage economies of scale to undercut camera stores' prices. Consumers have more access to information about camera quality and specifications than ever, making the expertise camera stores provide less valuable.

The upstream camera manufacturing industry is extremely concentrated, with five Japanese companies dominating the market by leveraging solid brand reputations. These companies are vertically integrating by opening flagship retail stores that bring yet another alternative to camera stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Digital age will continue to batter the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: E-commerce sales will continue to flourish as consumers prefer the convenience and prices offered by online retailers. Smartphone technology is set to advance more, reducing relevance of cameras. Remaining demand will be serviced by cheaper alternatives.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Inventory options shift towards premium cameras
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Camera stores will offer more high-end cameras to cater to professional photographers, who will remain a key source of demand. Stores will shrink workforces and hire more skilled workers to elevate in-store experience.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Razor-thin profit will force many out of industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The competitive environment will pressure camera stores to keep prices low, limiting revenue from already lackluster demand. Many stores will struggle to turn a profit and be forced out of business.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Strong disposable income will slow revenue loss
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As inflation settles, rising disposable income will allow some consumers to purchase new cameras from stores, slowing the industry's revenue decline over the next five years.

industry_definition: This industry comprises brick-and-mortar camera stores that primarily sell photographic equipment such as cameras, lighting equipment, film, tripods and other camera accessories. E-commerce, consumer electronic stores and catalog sales are not included in this industry.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady barriers to entry level

key_trends: Demand for personal cameras from everyday consumers has remained relatively low
Many operators are exiting the industry, and many of those that remain are laying off workers
Competing retailers are able to sell higher volumes of goods at lower prices, undercutting industry operators
Post-pandemic temporary growth has provided relief, but does not aid standalone cameras against outside competition
Smartphones will likely cut considerably into the industry's market
Camera stores will likely focus on serving niche markets
The industry has declined for over a decade and will likely continue to do so

market_segmentation.segment_description: The largest revenue stream comes from households buying new cameras for the first time or adding to their collection. This segment's share will modestly rise as digital camera prices fall.
This segment is composed of purchases made by households to replace broken or outdated cameras. It has declined as smartphones displace standalone cameras and high-end models have longer life spans.
This includes businesses like portrait studios and wedding photographers that use photography equipment as a resource. Most businesses prefer hiring outside marketing teams for advertising though.
Camera retailers occasionally sell products to wholesalers and other stores when facing shortages, but this is a marginal portion of revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Interchangeable lenses grant photographers versatility for different shooting scenarios like portraits, weddings, macro, sports etc. The market parallels interchangeable lens camera growth.
Interchangeable lens digital cameras like DSLRs and nonreflex models are the top product, allowing users to switch lenses for flexibility and creativity. Digital has become standard over film.

Point-and-shoot cameras with built-in lenses are a niche market, as smartphones have led to a significant drop in their popularity. Some influencers and professionals still prefer them over interchangeable lens cameras.

tier_1_suppliers: Audio & Video Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Camera & Film Wholesaling in the US
Semiconductor Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Copier & Optical Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Wholesale Trade Agents and Brokers in the US
tier_2_buyers: Fine Arts Schools in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Since cameras are discretionary purchases, demand is highly sensitive to changes in consumer confidence and per capita disposable income. Higher income and confidence lead to more willingness to buy cameras.

Demand for cameras is affected by prices of products in other entertainment industries like travel, music and film. Lower prices in these industries can reduce demand for cameras as consumers find alternatives more cost-effective.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports and exports not directly accounted for
international_trade_points.trade_description: While nearly all cameras sold are produced internationally, retailers don't directly participate in international trade. Import and export figures are accounted for in upstream manufacturing industries.
According to 2021 data, Japanese companies account for 94.4% of the global camera market.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest number of camera stores, as a quarter of the nation's population lives in this region.
The Mid-Atlantic region has the second highest number of camera stores after the Southeast.
The West region has a balanced percentage of camera store establishments and population.
The Great Lakes region has a balanced percentage of camera store establishments and population.
The Southwest region has a balanced percentage of camera store establishments and population.
The Plains region has a lower percentage of camera store establishments due to lower population density.
The New England region has a balanced percentage of camera store establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountain region has a lower percentage of camera store establishments due to lower population density.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Camera stores need to abide by general consumer protection laws, which typically include regulations regarding fair advertising practices, accurate product labeling, warranty disclosures and handling customer complaints or returns. These can vary from state to state, though.

Wide-reaching stay-at-home orders through the height of the COVID-19 pandemic devastated camera stores, which rely on foot traffic. Most camera stores had no remote infrastructure and lost business accordingly.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has a low level of regulation, making entry easier. Still, new camera stores will need to understand and comply with broad retailer laws aimed at consumer and workforce protection.

The moderate start-up costs to establish a store and acquire expensive and wide-ranging inventory can be a deterrent, particularly with constant capital requirements to maintain a supply of camera equipment.

New camera stores will find it challenging to compete with big-box stores and online retailers who have more resources and can offer competitive prices and convenience, especially in an atmosphere where consumer preference is shifting towards e-commerce.
Most employees in this industry are low-skilled workers, which means that emerging companies will likely have access to a large, inexpensive network of potential employees.

basis_points.basis_title: Price, product variety and customer service
basis_points.basis_description: For camera stores, competition is primarily based on price, product variety and customer service. As camera purchases are usually discretionary, stores need to offer competitive prices to attract customers– a priority made more pressing by the convenience of online price comparisons.
Regardless of the approach, having available products from key brands like Canon, Sony and Nikon is crucial for retailers to stay relevant with consumers.

Customer service and product expertise also play a significant role in competition between stores. Knowledgeable retail staff can help build a positive reputation for a store, attracting customers and sales.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The average camera store currently employs just three to four workers, illustrating the small scale of these businesses. Camera stores are largely independent and serve local, niche markets, resulting in a low level of industry concentration.

As long as they have the necessary products from the top three camera brands, consumers aren't usually loyal to any particular retailer. Camera stores are facing dropping demand that is forcing stores to permanently close every year, which makes opening a second location and expanding brand influence near-impossible.
With profit as low as it is across the industry, there's no opportunity for camera stores to buy out competitors and boost their market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Slim Profit Pushes Smaller Stores Out of the Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is even tighter for most retailers, as the few larger camera stores can minimize costs by buying inventory in bulk and spreading fixed costs out over a larger sales volume.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are down as workforces shrink
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Camera stores are laying off employees and cutting back on the number of workers in a store at a given time as demand continues to shrink and foot traffic slows. Per-employee pay is up, though, as stores seek to bring in customers by offering expertise and hiring more skilled workers with sales training.

Stores spend most of their capital acquiring expensive inventory, and stores need a wide range of products that cater to both casual hobbyists and professional photographers. Product availability is especially important to brick-and-mortar stores, as instant availability is one of the main competitive advantages that this business model holds over online retailers. Upstream camera manufacturers enjoy higher profit than camera stores since most cameras sold are from three dominant brands that have the power to set prices that camera stores lack.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Camera stores contend with a medium level of capital intensity. IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages in 2022, the average industry player will spend $0.17 for capital investment. Stores invest in warehousing space, equipment, cash registers and online commerce portals.
Camera retailers have increasingly implemented automated inventory and point-of-sale systems, both of which are capital investments, this industry remains heavily dependent on inventory and labor.

Camera store employees are often expected to process purchases and maintain store displays, in addition to providing customers with knowledgeable and specialized assistance. Labor costs have become even more integral to a camera store's success as many retailers have only been able to remain competitive against external competitors by presenting their workers as experts that can assist customers with the more technical aspects of cameras and photography. As a result, labor costs for this industry have generally been larger than capital investments.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility spiked amid the coronavirus pandemic and recovery, as economic downturn and public wellness initiatives aimed to curb the virus' spread forced camera stores to temporarily close down. As regulations lifted, renewed foot traffic and consumer spending restored some lost revenue as pent-up demand was released.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DEMAND DEPENDS ON SOLID DISPOSABLE INCOME
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cameras are a discretionary purchase for most consumers, so camera stores depend on consumers having enough extra cash to justify a nonessential purchase. Cameras are also expensive, so sales of them are very sensitive to fluctuations in per capita disposable income. Heavy inflation in 2022 raised the price of many consumers' essential bills and grocery store trips, leaving them with plummeting disposable income. This further heightened volatility and continued to push the industry's downward spiral forward.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Pure-play camera stores have to deal with external competition. Most notably, the technological advancement and widespread consumer adoption of smartphones has given consumers a more convenient and versatile option for taking pictures and directly fueled the industry's decline. As smartphone cameras continue to develop to meet the requirements of photography enthusiasts, consumers simply won't be able justify carrying a standalone camera. Camera stores have struggled to stay afloat amid disruption, forcing many stores to permanently close up shop.

Camera stores are embracing cutting-edge technology and systems to streamline their business operations and enhance the experience for their customers. Modern point-of-sale (POS) systems effortlessly handle transactions, and online inventory management tools can help stores avoid losses and delays. Some camera stores have even been able to rollout online platforms that cater to consumer demand for convenience. Camera stores are also harnessing the power of social media and digital marketing tools to amplify their reach and engage with photography enthusiasts.

FAQs.question: What are some key points about COVID-19 lockdowns and their impact on camera stores?
FAQs.answer: Wide-reaching stay-at-home orders through the height of the COVID-19 pandemic devastated camera stores, which rely on foot traffic. Most camera stores had no remote infrastructure and lost business accordingly.

FAQs.question: What kind of industry assistance or support is available for camera stores?
FAQs.answer: Camera stores benefit from industry-specific trade organizations like Photo Trade News and the Photo Marketing Association International (PMA) which provide educational resources and host conferences. Some camera manufacturers and distributors also offer financing options to retailers.

FAQs.question: How have camera stores adapted their sales and marketing strategies?
FAQs.answer: Camera stores offer a wide range of cameras to attract diverse consumers. However, competition from online retailers and consumer electronic stores has reduced in-store purchases as consumers prioritize convenience. Many stores have developed online stores to compete more effectively.

FAQs.question: What strategies do camera stores use for operations and growth?
FAQs.answer: Stores focus on providing a comprehensive in-person shopping experience by maintaining knowledgeable staff. Some dominant stores may acquire smaller specialized companies in desirable locations to expand reach and reduce overhead.

FAQs.question: How do camera stores use technology?
FAQs.answer: While many stores invest in automated inventory and point-of-sale systems to run more efficiently, the industry remains labor-intensive overall. Having an online presence is an important competitive advantage as convenience factors into consumer decisions.

FAQs.question: What are the key compliance requirements for camera stores?
FAQs.answer: The industry is subject to a low level of regulation, mainly to ensure a free and competitive economy. Stores must comply with employee health and operation regulations set by OSHA.

FAQs.question: How do camera stores manage finances and profitability?
FAQs.answer: Profit can vary significantly between operators, with larger stores able to minimize costs through bulk purchasing and distributing fixed costs. Successful operations rely on keeping the newest, most technologically advanced products in stock.

FAQs.question: What factors are important for camera store operations?
FAQs.answer: Key factors include attractive product presentation, knowledgeable and experienced workforce, proximity to key markets with high foot traffic, and monitoring impact of mobile internet and e-commerce on demand.

FAQs.question: How does per capita disposable income affect the industry?
FAQs.answer: During periods of low or declining per capita disposable income, camera store sales traditionally suffer as consumers forego purchases of luxury items like cameras.
